body:
Tried adopting the "DISABLING ARES" line from @timburks' grpc-swift repository https://github.com/grpc/grpc-swift/blob/master/vendor-grpc.sh#L75-L76 like so

```
mkdir ~/install
cd ~/install
git clone -b $(curl -L https://grpc.io/release) https://github.com/grpc/grpc
cd grpc
git submodule update --init
perl -pi -e 's/#define GRPC_ARES 1/#define GRPC_ARES 0/' include/grpc/impl/codegen/port_platform.h
LIBTOOL=glibtool LIBTOOLIZE=glibtoolize make
```
No success. The installation continues to barf with the same aforementioned warnings.

Further, running
```
grep -r "GRPC_ARES" .
```
within a freshly cloned gRPC repository suggests that GRPC_ARES seems to be set to 0 everywhere.

```
./config.w32:    "/D_HAS_EXCEPTIONS=0 /DNOMINMAX /DGRPC_ARES=0 /D_WIN32_WINNT=0x600 "+
./include/grpc/impl/codegen/port_platform.h:#ifndef GRPC_ARES
./include/grpc/impl/codegen/port_platform.h:#define GRPC_ARES 0
./include/grpc/impl/codegen/port_platform.h:#define GRPC_ARES 1
./gRPC-Core.podspec:  s.compiler_flags = '-DGRPC_ARES=0'
./config.m4:    -D_HAS_EXCEPTIONS=0 -DNOMINMAX -DGRPC_ARES=0)
./grpc.gyp:      'GRPC_ARES=0',
./setup.py:                    ('GRPC_ARES', 0), ('NTDDI_VERSION', 0x06000000),)
./bazel/grpc_build_system.bzl:    defines = select({"//:grpc_no_ares": ["GRPC_ARES=0"],
./templates/gRPC-Core.podspec.template:    s.compiler_flags = '-DGRPC_ARES=0'
./templates/config.w32.template:      "/D_HAS_EXCEPTIONS=0 /DNOMINMAX /DGRPC_ARES=0 /D_WIN32_WINNT=0x600 "+
./templates/grpc.gyp.template:        'GRPC_ARES=0',
./templates/config.m4.template:      -D_HAS_EXCEPTIONS=0 -DNOMINMAX -DGRPC_ARES=0)
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver_posix.cc:#if GRPC_ARES == 1 && defined(GRPC_POSIX_SOCKET)
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver_posix.cc:#endif /* GRPC_ARES == 1 && defined(GRPC_POSIX_SOCKET) */
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.h:#ifndef GRPC_CORE_EXT_FILTERS_CLIENT_CHANNEL_RESOLVER_DNS_C_ARES_GRPC_ARES_WRAPPER_H
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.h:#define GRPC_CORE_EXT_FILTERS_CLIENT_CHANNEL_RESOLVER_DNS_C_ARES_GRPC_ARES_WRAPPER_H
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.h:#endif /* GRPC_CORE_EXT_FILTERS_CLIENT_CHANNEL_RESOLVER_DNS_C_ARES_GRPC_ARES_WRAPPER_H \
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc:#if GRPC_ARES == 1 && !defined(GRPC_UV)
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc:#endif /* GRPC_ARES == 1 && !defined(GRPC_UV) */
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver.h:#ifndef GRPC_CORE_EXT_FILTERS_CLIENT_CHANNEL_RESOLVER_DNS_C_ARES_GRPC_ARES_EV_DRIVER_H
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver.h:#define GRPC_CORE_EXT_FILTERS_CLIENT_CHANNEL_RESOLVER_DNS_C_ARES_GRPC_ARES_EV_DRIVER_H
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver.h:#endif /* GRPC_CORE_EXT_FILTERS_CLIENT_CHANNEL_RESOLVER_DNS_C_ARES_GRPC_ARES_EV_DRIVER_H \
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/dns_resolver_ares.cc:#if GRPC_ARES == 1 && !defined(GRPC_UV)
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/dns_resolver_ares.cc:#else /* GRPC_ARES == 1 && !defined(GRPC_UV) */
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/dns_resolver_ares.cc:#endif /* GRPC_ARES == 1 && !defined(GRPC_UV) */
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper_fallback.cc:#if GRPC_ARES != 1 || defined(GRPC_UV)
./src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper_fallback.cc:#endif /* GRPC_ARES != 1 || defined(GRPC_UV) */
```

Is there something obvious that I am missing?

Can you please help me understand what could I be doing wrong? I am attempting installation from source on a Mac. This should not feel like a visit to the dentist, except that I am running out of ideas.

@muxi @timburks

@ncteisen @vjpai @ctiller @nathanielmanistaatgoogle @jcanizales 

Apologies for looping you folks in. However, I am unable to get installation from source to work on a Mac for some time now. In case you are not the correct folks for this, could you please share the correct folks/mechanism/channel to communicate this? I am hoping to not post this issue again on the gRPC google group, in order to avoid duplication.

Additionally, I am unable to understand the rationale for c-ares, given that GRPC_ARES seems to be set to 0 for most, if not all, build mechanisms (bazel et al). This is based on my limited knowledge of grepping and absolutely no understanding of the underlying code or what c-ares does. It is purely from a perspective of someone trying to get gRPC to build for the last 2 weeks, albeit unsuccessfully.
```
./gRPC-Core.podspec:  s.compiler_flags = '-DGRPC_ARES=0'
./config.m4:    -D_HAS_EXCEPTIONS=0 -DNOMINMAX -DGRPC_ARES=0)
./grpc.gyp:      'GRPC_ARES=0',
./setup.py:                    ('GRPC_ARES', 0), ('NTDDI_VERSION', 0x06000000),)
./bazel/grpc_build_system.bzl:    defines = select({"//:grpc_no_ares": ["GRPC_ARES=0"],
```
The above snippet is from the full output of
```
grep -r "GRPC_ARES"
```
which is present in the comment preceding the previous comment.

c ares is the async DNS resolver we use.

Can you try installing c ares first? Something like:
```
cd third_party/cares
make
[sudo] make install
```

(or something like that, there may be a `./configure` step somewhere. Can give a more detailed answer next week)

Danke @ncteisen for the response. However, unfortunately, your suggestion did not work.
```
cd third_party/cares/cares
make
make: *** No targets specified and no makefile found.  Stop.
./configure
No such file or directory
```
Would it be possible to please verify if the current gRPC makefile actually works? I ask this because I am not sure if the currently documented mechanism using make files is being used by anyone. I may be wrong here, but I base this on the following things:
1) The consistent failures that I have been facing.
2) The lack of said failures being reported by anyone else.
3) The lack of requisite commands in the make file to actually mkdir cp anything to the "$(LIBDIR)/$(CONFIG)/c-ares" directory. Please see my Initial Investigation in the issue report.
4) The disabling of GRPC_ARES in almost all build mechanisms, except the make one.

Additionally, would it help if Bazel was used to build? If yes, could you please share the instructions?

Hi there,
Just to confirm: this is only a warning, correct? I usually use bazel (where we do have a known issue on the mac of getting some excess warnings about pthreads), but I can repro the warning that you've described if I use make. But given that it's just a warning, this seems like more of an inconvenience than a "trip to the dentist" . Is the installation actually "barf"ing or just producing some warnings?

Danke @vjpai for your response.

From what I understand, and I may be wrong here - an attempt to install should not produce warnings. Especially, in such numbers. I think it is a good practice to not proceed and to report these warnings. Case in point - https://github.com/projectNe10/Ne10/issues/123 - reporting usually gets them fixed, and might help uncover underlying issues.

May be this may not seem like a "trip to the dentist", and may be this may not qualify as an installation "barf"ing, but I hope you would not consider this to be par for the course - installation from source following canonical instructions on a fresh machine producing a stream of warnings.

As regards to it being more of an inconvenience, I would request you to please refer to this thread - https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/grpc-io/eVdtmWufE5w (linked in the original issue).

In case I am missing an obvious solution, I apologize and request you to please share the same.
Oh, I'm not saying that this isn't a problem. I'm just trying to gauge its relative priority. I think we should address this but it may take a bit of time.
